Tampering.description: An attacker can modify your build system and produce signed builds of your software.
An attacker can take advantage of your custom key exchange or integrity control which you built instead of using standard crypto.
Your code makes access control decisions all over the place, rather than with a security kernel.
An attacker can replay data without detection because your code doesn't provide timestamps or sequence numbers.
Tampering.MITRE ATT&CK: T1565.003 - Data Manipulation: Data from Untrusted Sources

Tampering.description: An attacker can write to a data store your code relies on.
An attacker can bypass permissions because you don't make names canonical before checking access permissions.
Tampering.MITRE ATT&CK: T1222.001 - File and Directory Permissions Modification: Linux and Mac

Tampering.description: An attacker can manipulate data because there's no integrity protection for data on the network.
Tampering.MITRE ATT&CK: T1565.002 - Data Manipulation: Transmitted Data Manipulation

Tampering.description: An attacker can provide or control state information.
Tampering.MITRE ATT&CK: T1553.004 - Hijack Execution Flow: Web Session Cookie

Tampering.description: An attacker can alter information in a data store because it has weak/open permissions or includes a group which is equivalent to everyone ('anyone with a Facebook account').
Tampering.MITRE ATT&CK: T1222.001 - File and Directory Permissions Modification: Linux and Mac

Tampering.description: An attacker can write to some resource because permissions are granted to the world or there are no ACLs.
Tampering.MITRE ATT&CK: T1222.001 - File and Directory Permissions Modification: Linux and Mac

Tampering.description: An attacker can change parameters over a trust boundary and after validation (for example, important parameters in a hidden field in HTML, or passing a pointer to critical memory).
An attacker can load code inside your process via an extension point.
Tampering.MITRE ATT&CK: T1505.003 - Server-Side Request Forgery: Web Services

Tampering.description: An attacker injects malicious code into the source repository to alter the application's behavior without detection.
A threat actor modifies encryption routines to weaken cryptographic operations and facilitate decryption.
An attacker exploits inadequate input validation to overwrite application data via a buffer overflow attack.
A hacker alters database queries within the application to bypass business logic and manipulate data access.
An adversary modifies the application's runtime environment to execute unauthorized commands or access data.
An attacker alters API endpoints to redirect users to malicious destinations or intercept data.
An attacker manipulates file permissions on shared resources to gain unauthorized access to sensitive data.
Tampering.MITRE ATT&CK: T1222.002 - File and Directory Permissions Modification: Windows

Tampering.description: A cybercriminal alters log files to hide evidence of an ongoing attack or past intrusions.
An attacker changes network device configurations to reroute traffic through a monitored gateway.
A threat actor inserts malicious code into third-party libraries used by the application to leverage widespread vulnerabilities.
